<lemepagenote type="display">
<term lang="un">
l e m e . l i b r a r y . u t o r o n t o . c a

s t c 6 7 4 8

v e r . 1 . 0  ( 2 0 1 8 )
</term>
</lemepagenote>
<section type="Title-page">
A
Dictionarie French 
and English:
Published for the benefite of the stu&shy;
dious in that language:

Gathered and set forth by Clau&shy;
dius Hollyband.

For the better vnderstanding of the or&shy;
der of this Dictionarie, peruse the
Preface to the Reader.

<term lang="la">Dum spiro, spero.</term>

Imprinted at London by T.O. for
Thomas Woodcock. 1593.
</section>


</page>

<page sig="a1v">


</page>

<page sig="a2r">
<section type="Dedication">

<heading>
<term lang="fr">A Tres-noble, Honorable, &amp; ver&shy;
tueux Seigneur, Monseigneur Edward
Zouche, ferme base, pillier et vray
Mec&oelig;nas de toutes mes
estudes.</term>
</heading>

<term lang="fr">COmme ainsi soit que la natu&shy;
re et inclination des humains
est differ<expan type="e+_">en</expan>te et diverse, pour la
plus part: aussi sont les juge&shy;
ments et desseings d'un chas&shy;
cun en particulier differents et
divers, selon que les occurren&shy;
ces, rencontres, et objects cor&shy;
respondent et symbolizent avec leurs affections: en
sorte que difficilement en trouvons nous deux, aus&shy;
quelz vne mesme chose plaise en tout poinct, &amp; sans
contre-dict quelconque: ains, selon l'ancient pro&shy;
verbe, Chascun &agrave; sa guise. Et cecy n'experimentons
nous seulement aux elections des pa&auml;s, contr&eacute;es, vil&shy;
les, situations et terroirs: mais aussi au chois des ars,
tant mechaniques, que liberaux. Mais que dy-je des
ars et sciences, veu que mesmes nous differons en la
poursuite des vertus? Qu<expan type="a+_">an</expan>t est des vices, nous n'en
faisons point de chois, si nous ne sommes du tout
d&eacute;naturez. Or si lon me dit, que les malins eslisent</term>


</page>

<page sig="a2v">
<term lang="fr">plus tost le mal que le bien, mesme qu'ilz se plaisent
en mal-faisant, je diray seulement, laisssant ceste que&shy;
stion indecise, que nous sommes promps au mal, &amp;
par trop duits, choisissans, &agrave; pr<expan type="e+_">en</expan>dre le pite. Mais, bon
Dieu, et qui nous meine ainsi &agrave; tors et &agrave; travers?
mesme &agrave; vn labyrinthe et gouffre de toute impiet&eacute;?
qui est, en somme, ce tant detestable pech&eacute; d'ingrati&shy;
tude: lequel, &agrave; mon advis, est si abhorrant de l'uma&shy;
nit&eacute;, que mesmes les bestes sauvages l'ont heu en
haine, fuy, et evit&eacute;: je n'entens pas des plus trai&shy;
tables, mais bien des cruels et plus fiers lyons, les&shy;
quelz par signes externes ont monstr&eacute; de recognoi&shy;
stre les biens et benefices receux des homes, et aultres
petites bestelettes. Et nous qui sommes creatures
raisonnables, n'ensuyvrons nous en rien ce petit di&shy;
stique, ou semblable?

Le plus grand bien dont l'home est revestu,
C'est quand de Dieu il ensuit la vertu.

Or est-il notoire &agrave; tous, que Dieu ha&auml;st et persecu&shy;
te sur tout aultre, ce tant detestable vice d'ingrati&shy;
tude: ostant le plus souvent, et privant les ingrats
des biens, dons, et graces. lesquelz au paravant il leur
avoir liberallement eslargis. Donc, Monseigneur,
pour n'estre trouv&eacute; au rang et trac de telles gens, j'em&shy;
brasseray ce, dont cestui-cy m'admonneste.

Ceux que verras en ce monde bien vivre,
Ce font ceux-la qu'il te convient ensuyvre.

D'entre lesquelz j'ay choisi les memoratifs et re&shy;
cognoissans les gentillesses receu&euml;s: desquelles, Mon&shy;
seigneur, vous n'avez tellement combl&eacute; en vostre
long, lointain, penible et dangereux voyage d'oultre</term>


</page>

<page sig="a3r">
<term lang="fr">mer, que vous vous estes plus-tost monstr&eacute; pere, ou
baston de vieillesse en mon endroit, que non pas mai&shy;
stre, Seigneur, our commandeur: de maniere que ny
&agrave; moy, ny &agrave; tout vostre train et suite, rien n'a man&shy;
qu&eacute;, voire en lieu ou n'y avoit creature vivante, tant
sagement aviez prouveu &amp;a grave; tout event. Et mesme si je
vouloye, ou bien osoye discourir de vostre liberalit&eacute;
en general envers les estrangers, mais en particulier
gens de s&ccedil;avoir, et d'esprit, du soin et estude que
vous avez employ&eacute; pour enrichir les facultez de l'e&shy;
sprit, je ne vouldroye proposer devant les yeux de
tous voyagers aultre exemplaire et patron, que cel&shy;
luy lequel je vous ay veu embrasser et suyvre. Mais
d'aultrant que je cognoye vostre modestie, Mon&shy;
seigneur, je n'entreprendray pour le present, &agrave; hault&shy;
lou&euml;r voz vertus hero&iuml;ques: maid seulement &grave; vostre
arriv&eacute;e tant desir&eacute;e en Angleterre, et en recognoi&shy;
ssance des faveurs lesquelles vous m'avez faites sa&shy;
vourer, je vous offriray ce present faisceau de plu&shy;
sieurs mots, peu de sentences, et moins de pro&shy;
verbes icy semez et espars, en ce mien Dictio&shy;
naire: lesquelz toutes-fois, s'ilz sont recueuillis et
bien assortis ensemble, comme vostre Seigneurie
en s&ccedil;ait fort bien le style, ilz rendront vne sym&shy;
metrie bien concordante, et vn son doux et har&shy;
monieux.

Vous supplyant, Monseigneur, de l'accepter com&shy;
me venant de celuy qui ne desire que &agrave; vous faire
tout humble service, et mettre en avant chose pour
l'esclarcissement et facilit&eacute; de nostre langue Fran&shy;
&ccedil;oise, en laquelle je s&ccedil;ay que prenez vn singulier</term>


</page>

<page sig="a3v">
<term lang="fr">plaisir: afin que vous les studieux et desireux d'icel&shy;
le, en sachent gr&eacute; &agrave; vostre Seigneurie, et moy &agrave; icelle
sois de plus en plus, tenu et oblig&eacute;: &agrave; laquelle
bien humblement voud baisant les mains, tous
mes travaux je recommende. De Lon&shy;
dres ce dixiesme jour de 
Avril, 1593.

Par le tout vostre
Desainliens.</term>
</section>


</page>

<page sig="a4r">
<section type="To the Reader" lang="en">
<heading>
Claudius Holliband, to the Students
of the French tongue.
</heading>

HAuing alreadie (gentle Reader) for
thine ease and facilitie in attaining
of our French tongue, set foorth my
Bookes <term lang="la">De pronunciatione lingu&aelig; 
gallic&aelig;</term>, &amp; French Littleton , where&shy;
by I haue opened the way to all sorts
aswell learned as vnlearned, for the
perfect reading and pronunciation
thereof: and yet perceiuing thy want
and indigence of a sufficient meane for the vnderstanding of the
same, I haue now for thy further auaile, published this my pre&shy;
sent worke, whereby for the most part, thou maiest be satisfied.
For, besides that I haue expounded all the hard words by diuers
and sundrie examples, I haue furthermore giuen thee the
Theame and principall Tenses of all our most difficult Verbes. I
call the Theame, speaking to the vnskilfull in the Latin tongue,
whereby we begin to decline a Verbe, as by example: In other
Dictionaries thou hast onely the Infinitiue moode of any Verbe,
as <term lang="fr">Aimer</term>, to loue: <term lang="fr">Vouloir</term>, to will or to be willing: <term lang="fr">Lire</term>, to reade,
<term lang="fr">Fuir</term>, to run away: and yet for all that thou art not much the wi&shy;
ser, because thou knowest not how to begin in the present tense, so
that thou canst say in French, to loue, <term lang="fr">Aimer</term>: but thou doest tra&shy;
uaile to say, I loue, thou louest, I haue loued, read, taught, I shall
or will goe, sleepe, play, walke, &amp;c. And behold, here I deliuering
thee out of such perplexitie, doe set it very plainly before thine
eyes, thus: First I doe specifie the Infinitiue moode, <term lang="fr">Parler</term>, to
speake: <term lang="fr">Courir</term>, to run: and straightway I shewe the present
tense of the Indicatiue, which is, <term lang="fr">je parle</term>, I doe speake: then fol&shy;
loweth the first perfect tense, <term lang="fr">je parlay</term>, I spake: thirdly, the se&shy;
cond perfect, <term lang="fr">j'ay parl&eacute;</term>, I haue spoken: Last of all the future
tense, <term lang="fr">je parleray</term>, I shal or will speake: so that thine order goeth
thus: to speake: then thou beginnest, I speake, I spake, I haue spo&shy;
ken, I shall or will speake: and so thou must iudge of the rest: do


</page>

<page sig="a4v">
that hauing al these tenses, thou maiest easily decline any verbe
through all moodes and tenses, because all the rest are deriued
and formed of those which be here specified in this Dictionarie,
as from their head spring. And yet to ease thee the better in
this thy labour, I haue put forth to light a little worke, called A
Treatise of Verbes: so that hauing here thy chiefest Tenses, and
in that Pamphlet the examples of all the Coniugations declined
at length through all moodes and tenses, with the Heteroclites:
ioyning these three workes togither, that is, the French Little&shy;
ton, or my sayd booke <term lang="la">De Pronuntiatione</term>, this Dictionarie, &amp;
my Treatise of Verbes, thou shalt haue occasion, I trust, taking
my labour in good part, to giue me thankes. Furthermore, I ad&shy;
uise thee to make a difference betweene this, j, which is a conso&shy;
nant, and the other, i, common: likewise of this, v, in the middest
of the word, least thou shouldest pronounce it as this u, being a
vowell: and that thou looke not for the theame and tenses of all
Verbes, whose Infinitiue doe end in er, as <term lang="fr">enseigner, bailler,</term> be&shy;
cause they be the easiest to be found of all the rest: for hauing the
Infinitiue moode, one may finde the present tense, by taking away
r, as of <term lang="fr">marcher, trencher</term>, you say, <term lang="fr">je marche,</term> I goe: <term lang="fr">je tren&shy;
che,</term>, I doe cut: all whose declining you may frame by these two
Verbes <term lang="fr">Abandonner</term>, and <term lang="fr">Abbayer</term>, which you shall finde at the
first page of this booke: which cannot be sayd of Verbes whose
Infinitiue doe end in <term lang="fr">oir, re,</term> or <term lang="fr">it</term>: the which for the most part,
haue a speciall or particular forming of their Theame and Ten&shy;
ses. Finally, our learner shall knowe our three genders, thus: the
Masculine gender is knowne by this letter, m: the Feminine, by 
f: the Common of two, com. But why doe I keepe thee so long,
seeing that all these difficulties be made easie by our sayd Trea&shy;
tise of Verbes? Take then, these our labours to thy furthe&shy;
rance, praying the Lord, so to blesse thy studies, that
it may redound to his honour and glorie, and
the commodities of the Com&shy;
mon weale.
</section>

<section type="Dictionary">


</page>

<page sig="b1r">
<wordgroup1 type="a" object="A"><alpha></alpha>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="a(d)">one of the sixe vowels in the
French tung, <term lang="fr">a,e,i,o,u</term> and <term lang="fr">y</term>,
is pronounced fully with an open
mouth, and hath diuers significati&shy;
ons: first, it is the third person sin&shy;
gular of the verbe, <term lang="fr">i'ay</term>, I haue: <term lang="fr">tu
as</term>, thou hast: <term lang="fr">il a</term>, he hath: as, <term lang="fr">Ie&shy;
han Wheeler a de bon vin</term>: Iohn
Wheeler hath good Wine. <term lang="fr">Le Roy
a vne grand'arm&eacute;e</term>: the king hath
a great armie. Sometimes being
ioyned with a participle, expresseth
the perfect tense of th' indicative
moode: as, <term lang="fr">Thomas Barns a faict
le voyage des Indes</term>, Thomas
Barns hath made the voiage of the
Indes: <term lang="fr">Ma fame a passe sa cholere</term>,
my wife hath asswaged hir choler.
Many times it serueth to expresse
the Datiue case: as, <term lang="fr">Ie l'ay don&shy;
n&eacute; &agrave; mon pere</term>, I gaue it to my Fa&shy;
ther. Sometime it serueth for the
Preposition To: as, <term lang="fr">Ie m'en vay &agrave;
mon pere</term>, I goe to my Father: <term lang="fr">&agrave;
Paris</term>, to Paris: <term lang="fr">&agrave; la ville</term>, to the
towne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A cause, &agrave; cueur, &agrave; droict, &agrave; l'aduen&shy;
ture, &agrave; loisir, &agrave; propos, &agrave; raison, &agrave;
s&ccedil;auoir, &agrave; temps, &agrave; tort, &amp; sembla&shy;
bles,</form> <xpln lang="en">seeke, <term lang="fr">Cause, Cueur, Droict,
&amp;c</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="in(pp)">is taken sometime for, <term lang="fr">en</term>, as, <term lang="fr">&agrave; la
presence des Evesques</term>, in the
presence of the Bishops.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="for(pp)">sometime signifieth <term lang="fr">pour</term>, for: as,
<term lang="fr">il est tenu &agrave; perdu</term>, it is counted
for lost: <term lang="fr">&agrave; sot</term>, for a foole: <term lang="fr">&agrave; fable</term>,
for a tale or lye: <term lang="fr">&agrave; filz de roy</term>, for
the Kings sonne.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="with(pp)">sometime is taken for <term lang="fr">avec</term>, with:
as, <term lang="fr">il est eschapp&eacute; &agrave; peu de perte</term>,
he is escaped with a small losse.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">A,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="like(adv)" lexeme="after the fashion(adv)" lexeme="after the manner(adv)">sometime is taken for like, or after
the fashion or manner, as, <term lang="fr">il est ve&shy;
stu &agrave; l'Italienne</term>, he is clothed af&shy;
ter the Italian fashion.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr"><term lang="en">Sometimes also</term> A,</form> <xpln lang="en">is taken for a
signe of the Infinitiue moode, as,
<term lang="fr">S'il a chose &agrave; dire &agrave; l'encontre,
qu'il le die</term>, if he hath any thing to
say against it, let him speak.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Aage,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="age(n)">age: <term lang="fr">m</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Bas age,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="under age(a)">vnder age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">L'aage de quatorze ans pour les
masles, et douze pour les femeles
</form> <xpln lang="en">th' age of fourteene yeeres is for
menkinde, and twelue for the fe&shy;
male kinde.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Ilz font tout d'un aage,</form> <xpln lang="en">they be of
like age.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Il est de ce'st aage l&agrave;:</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="of those days(adv)" lexeme="of that age(adv)">he is of that
age, that is, of those daies.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">En ce'st aage l&agrave;, il y avoit des gens
s&ccedil;avans,</form> <xpln lang="en">in that age there were
learned men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Des son jeune aage il a aym&eacute; Dieu,
</form> <xpln lang="en">euen from his childehoode he did
loue God.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Rapporter l'aage l'un &agrave; l'autre,</form> <xpln lang="en">to
confer both th' age together.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Selon que l'aage le porte, le permet
le souffre,</form> <xpln lang="en">as th' age beareth, re&shy;


</page>

<page sig="b1v">
quireth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Quel aage a-il?</form> <xpln lang="en">of what age is he?</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Home de bon aage,</form> <xpln lang="en">a man of good
age, or striken in yeeres.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Aag&eacute;, <term lang="fr">as</term>, il est aag&eacute; de six ans, de
dix ans, &amp;c.</form> <xpln lang="en">he is six yeares, ten 
yeeres of age, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Home fort aag&eacute;, ou de grand aage,
</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="old man(n)">a very olde man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Quel aage vous est-il aduis que
j'aye?</form> <xpln lang="en">of what age thinke you that I
am of?</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Estre plus aag&eacute; qu'vn autre,</form> <xpln lang="en">To be
older then an other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abaisser,</form> <xpln lang="en">seeke <term lang="fr">Abbaisser</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abandon,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="bandon(n)" lexeme="licence(n)" lexeme="liberty(n)">bandon, licence, liberty: <term lang="fr">m</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abandonner, j'abandonne, j'aban&shy;
donnay, j'ay abandonn&eacute;, j'aban&shy;
donneray,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="give over(v)" lexeme="licence(v)" lexeme="cast off(v)" lexeme="deliver(v)">to giue ouer, or to li&shy;
cence, to cast off: as also to deliuer
a thing to the libertie, will, or plea&shy;
sure of any man.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Vne femme abbandonn&eacute;e,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="common woman(n)">a wom<expan type="a+_">an</expan>
for euery mans lust or will, a com&shy;
mon woman.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">S'abbandonner &agrave; tous plaisirs,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="give to pleasures(v)">to
giue him selfe to all pleasures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbandonner femmes et enfans,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="forsake(v)">to
forsake wife and children.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Il m'a abbandonn&eacute; quand il estoit
question de ma vie,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="forsake(v)">he hath forsa&shy;
ken me vpon the point of my life.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Celuy duquel la vie est abban&shy;
donn&eacute;e au premier qui le tuera,
</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="outlaw(n)">an outlaw.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbandonn&eacute;e, <term lang="en">as</term> Encor que tou&shy;
tes choses me fussent abandon&eacute;es
et libres,</form> <xpln lang="en">though all things were at
my commaundement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abandonn&eacute;,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="forsaken(a)" lexeme="given over(a)" lexeme="cast off(a)">forsaken, giuen ouer,
cast off.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abandonnement,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="giving over(n)">a giuing ouer: <term lang="fr">m</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abandonn&eacute;ment,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="licentiously(adv)">licentiously.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abastardir, jabastardis, j'abastardi,
j'ay abastardi, j'abastardiray,
corrompre,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="corrupt(v)" lexeme="abastardise(v)" lexeme="counterfeit(v)">to corrupt, or abastar&shy;
dise, to counterfait.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abastardir,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="degenerate(v)">to degenerate.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbaisser, j'abbaisse, j'abbaissay,
j'ay abbaiss&eacute;, j'abbaisseray,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="abase(v)" lexeme="bring low(v)">to a&shy;
base or bring lowe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbaisser quelque chose en la de&shy;
sprisant,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="abate(v)" lexeme="bring low(v)">to abate or bring lowe a
thing in dispraising the same.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abaisser les vivres,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bring victuals
to a lower price.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Ie me fuy abbaiss&eacute; jusques l&agrave;,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="humble(v)">I haue
humbled my selfe so farre.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbaisseur,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="bring low(v)">he that bringeth low: <term lang="fr">m</term>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">La riuiere va en abbaissant,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="decrease(v)">the ri&shy;
uer decreaseth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbaiss&eacute;,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="abased(a)" lexeme="brought low(a)">abased or brought low.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbaissement de voix ou de son
estat,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="speaking soft(n)" lexeme="decay of estate(n)">a speaking soft, a decay of e&shy;
state.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Abbatre, j'abbas, j'abbati, j'ay ab&shy;
batu, j'abbatray,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="beat down(v)" lexeme="throw down(v)" lexeme="hew(v)" lexeme="hurl down(v)">to beate downe,
throwe downe, to hewe, to hurle
downe.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Il porte vn synople &agrave; trois Lyons
d'argent,</form> <xpln lang="en">he beareth a green shielde
with, &amp;c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">La faim et la soif abbatent le corps,
</form> <xpln lang="en">hunger and thirst do beate or bring
downe the body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Forcer,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="compel(v)" lexeme="force(v)" lexeme="ravish(v)" lexeme="break(v)" lexeme="pass through(v)">to compell, to force one, also to
rauishe and force a woman, also to
break: as <term lang="fr">il a <emend err="fotc&eacute;">forc&eacute;</emend> la porte</term>, he hath
broken the dore open: also to bring 
one to extremitie: as <term lang="fr">voil&agrave; vn cerf
forc&eacute; des chiens</term>, that is, a Hart o&shy;
uercome and without breath by the 
Hounds: Finally, to passe through,
as <term lang="fr">Il a forc&eacute; les gardes du chaste&shy;
au</term>, he is gone through the gardes of
the Fortresse.</xpln></wordentry>

a bowe is stronger in one side then in
the other: as <term lang="fr">mon arc forchasse, &amp;
forjecte</term>, my bow shooteth not right.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Lu mu de cerf,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="hart casts horns(v)" lexeme="mewing of a falcon(n)" lexeme="coop(n)" lexeme="sty(n)">when the Hart cast&shy;
eth his hornes: also the muing of a
Faulcon, it is taken also for the
place where hee doth mue: so we
say, <term lang="fr">mettre en mue, mettre hors de
mue</term>: also it is taken for a coupe or
stie where Capons or other beasts
are fatned: Finally, for a mockerie
we say, <term lang="fr">la mue d'vne fame</term>, when
through Phisicke &amp; drugs she hath
changed her wrinkled skinne into a
smooth and delicate hue.</xpln><lemenote>Word entry missing from the Henry E. Huntington copy in EEBO (STC 6737), supplied from the Leeds copy facsimile by Scolar Press.

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Pipp&eacute;e,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="counterfeited peeping and chirping(n)">is a worde counterfaited of
birds pieping or chirping, as also <term lang="fr">Pi&shy;
pe, Pipeur, &amp; Pipper</term>, and signifieth
the voice which a bird catcher doth
vse, either with a leafe, his knife,
or reede, or any other like thing, to 
haue the birdes to resorte to the
bushe where he is hidden with his
twigs of birdlime: So we say <term lang="fr">Pren&shy;
dre les oyseaux &agrave; la pip&eacute;e</term>, to catch
birdes after that sort: <term lang="fr">f</term></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Pip&eacute;e,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="countenance(n)" lexeme="counterfeited behaviour(n)">is taken for a countenance or
counterfaited behauiour, as <term lang="fr">Il fait
la bonne pip&eacute;e</term>, he sheweth a diss<expan type="e+_">em</expan>
bling face or countenance.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Pip&eacute;e,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="caught craftily(v)" lexeme="cogged with(v)" lexeme="deceived by craft(a)">is a Participle of the Passiue
signification: as <term lang="fr">Elle a est&eacute; pip&eacute;e</term>,
she was caught craftily, deceitfully.
<term lang="fr">I'ay est&eacute; pip&eacute;,</term> I haue beene cogged
with, that is, I haue beene deceiued
by craft.</xpln></wordentry>

mitteth any apostrophus at all.</xpln></wordentry>

sounded an alarme: <term lang="fr">sonner le toc&shy;
sing</term>, is when they will haue the
commons to rise, or when any house
is on fire, or to runne vpon their e&shy;
nemies, they strike hard and thicke
the greatest bell of the Parish, then
all the people runne as it were to the
outcrye, or the firing of beacons

lais,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="dead(n)">doubtfully spoken, for it may

seth for the dead, alluding to the 
custome of the Papists, sprinkling
the graues of the dead with holy <emend err="wa">wa&shy;</emend>
ter to clense their soules: but indeed 
it should be written, <term lang="fr">Il pisse pour
les traicts passez</term>, that is, he pisseth

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="fr">Vn vivier <term lang="en">or</term> estang,</form> <xpln lang="en" lexeme="little pool(n)" lexeme="pond(n)" lexeme="great pool(n)" lexeme="fishpond(n)" lexeme="stew(n)">a little poole, or
